sitewide.dateRange:
April 18 through April 20, 2023 (US)
April 19 through April 21, 2023 (Japan)

home.content1: UCLA, USC, Reitaku University, FAU, and MaptimeLA join forces to host the 6th Annual Humanitarian Mapathon, a free mapping competition to support the Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team (HOT). Everybody is welcome to attend, whether you have any mapping experience or not! Training will be provided to ensure that you are able to participate and contribute to humanitarian causes around the world.
home.content2: This three-day international hybrid event will include student speakers, hands-on training, donuts, prizes, and more. Join a community of humanitarian mappers, and let's all make a difference.
home.cardContent1: Register and get the mapathon Zoom link.
home.cardContent2: The mapathon will span a 3-day period spanning April 18 to April 20. Check out the full agenda here.
home.cardContent3: Follow our step-by-step tutorial and you'll be mapping in just a few minutes.
home.cardContent4: Join the channel to say "Hi", meet other mapathoners, and ask for help from our experts.
home.cardContent5: Check out the scores, but note that the leaderboard may a few hours update.

schedule.day1EventDescription2:
- Céline Jacquin

I am a French geographer who has lived in Mexico City for half part of my life, as an urban studies researcher and open data and civic technology activist through OpenStreetMap and other citizen science projects focused on urban mobility, gender, and community building like Geochicas. I have participated in various open governance programs at the university, at the World Resources Institute, and in two federal scientific institutions in Mexico (CONACyT and INEGI). I am involved as much as my time allows in diversity and inclusion activities within OSM. I have been a project manager for HOT in Latin America since 2021 and am now the Senior Manager of Community Programs for Latin America.
schedule.day2EventDescription2:
Lightning Talk Marathon

Format: 3 minute presentations

Round 1 (20 minutes)
  • UCLA
  • USC
  • Reitaku
  • Community
Round 2 (20 minutes)
  • UCLA
  • USC
  • Reitaku
  • Community
Round 3 (20 minutes)
  • UCLA
  • USC
  • Reitaku
  • Community
schedule.day3EventDescription2:
- Taichi Furuhashi

Taichi Furuhashi is passionate about mapping, connecting local communities with maps and sharing knowledge to empower people. As you know, Huge Earthquake and Tsunami destroyed a lot of cities and local communities in East Japan area in 2011. They are trying, how to make more resilient society with Mapping, Panorama/VR and Drone technology. Taichi is a professor of Aoyama Gakuin University and President of CrisisMappers Japan, NPO. Now he has started DRONEBIRD project with drones for Disaster Crisis Response.

resources.section1Content: To participate in the Mapathon, you will need to create both an OSM account and a HOT OSM account.
resources.resourceDescription1: Create an OSM account because it is required to use HOT OSM.
resources.resourceDescription2: HOT OSM is what you will use to participate in the Mapathon by contributing to humanitarian mapping projects.
resources.resourceDescription3: Use these tutorial slides to follow along with the presentation.
resources.resourceDescription4: Use this Google Doc to print out a quick guide.
resources.resourceDescription5: Use this quick start guide to get going!

team.section1Description1: I am a French geographer who has lived in Mexico City for half part of my life, as an urban studies researcher and open data and civic technology activist through OpenStreetMap and other citizen science projects focused on urban mobility, gender, and community building like Geochicas. I have participated in various open governance programs at the university, at the World Resources Institute, and in two federal scientific institutions in Mexico (CONACyT and INEGI). I am involved as much as my time allows in diversity and inclusion activities within OSM. I have been a project manager for HOT in Latin America since 2021 and am now the Senior Manager of Community Programs for Latin America.
team.section1Description2: Taichi Furuhashi is passionate about mapping, connecting local communities with maps and sharing knowledge to empower people. As you know, Huge Earthquake and Tsunami destroyed a lot of cities and local communities in East Japan area in 2011. They are trying, how to make more resilient society with Mapping, Panorama/VR and Drone technology. Taichi is a professor of Aoyama Gakuin University and President of CrisisMappers Japan, NPO. Now he has started DRONEBIRD project with drones for Disaster Crisis Response.
team.section1Description3: I’m a seismologist working at the GFZ German Research Centre for Geosciences. My working fields include seismic networks, earthquake hazard and risk and the building of a global multi-hazard exposure model describing each building’s vulnerability to different hazards.
team.section2Description1: Self-proclaimed map geek, passionate about all things at the nexus of geospatial technology, the social sciences and the humanities.
team.section2Description6: Ask me about spatial data science!
team.section2Description16: Ask me about geospatial technologies in the humanities and social sciences!
team.section2Description17: Ask me about OSM and GIS!
team.section2Description18: Ask me about critical cartography and the intersections of mapping and political geography!

about.pageContent: This Mapathon started as a joint event held by UCLA and USC for GIS Day. Below are links to the websites for past events.
